newsitem.title: USA: Rains improve Oklahoma winter wheat condition.
newsitem.headline: Rains improve Oklahoma winter wheat condition.

text.p: Rains improved hard red winter wheat conditions the week ended Sunday and the crop was rated 82 percent good to excellent, the state's agricultural statistics service said Monday.
Storms moved across the state during the week, improving soil moisture levels in most areas and bringing much-needed rainfall to struggling dryland wheat acreage in the panhandle.

Winter wheat was rated nil very poor, two percent poor, 16 percent fair, 69 percent goot and 13 percent excellent. Topsoil moisture was rated nil very short, six percent short, 81 percent adequate and 13 percent surplus.
Insect damage was said to be moderate. Soil-borne mosaic virus, barley yellow dwarf and rust were reported in several areas, the report said.
Row crop activity came to a halt late last week due to stormy weather but seedbed preparations were active early in the week.

"With the recent moisture, corn planting should pick up in the west central and the panhandle districts," the report said. "All row crop field activities are at or ahead of normal except for peanut field preparations."
